description: Microsoft Visual Studio Code (VS Code) is an open source , cross-platform code editor that developers can use to develop and debug applications. When developers want to work on multiple, related projects in VS Code at the same time, they can group those projects into a multi-root workspace. Doing so allows developers to open and switch between related projects using VS Code's EXPLORER sidebar, rather than opening each project in a separate instance of VS Code.

For example, a developer who wants to simultaneously open and edit an app's source code and its documentation can add both projects to a multi-root workspace. Then, as the developer updates the app's source code, they can update the app's documentation to reflect those code changes.

When a user saves a multi-root workspace (by selecting File â†’ Save Workspace As... from VS Code's menu bar), the workspace is saved as a CODE-WORKSPACE file. This file is a JSON file that contains a list of the root directories the workspace includes. When a user loads a workspace, VS Code uses these references to determine which folders to show in the EXPLORER sidebar.
